comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Whatever can that cryptic remark mean?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It means the answer is "beards" and the author displays a considerable ignorance of facial hair fashions in Roman and medieval Britain. Where's my prize?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Our Peregrine is a little miffed at you casting asparagus at his knowledge of facial hair fashions, so he's instructed me to tell you: "No prize, just the glory"...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: ungh, those f's instead of s's are ftrange...

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Mr Thomas Jackson's bookshop, 23 Parliament Street. maps.google.ie/maps?q=23+Parliament+Street,+Dublin&hl...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
I had a look for Mr Jackson in the Freeman's Journal and it turns out he was hugely involved in late-18th and early-19th century Lotteries...
STATE LOTTERY OFFICES, No. 23, Parliament-Street, and No. 3, New Sackville-Street. JACKSON, Respectfully informs the Public he has for their acommodations, opened a Second National Lottery-Office, No. 5, New Sackville- Street; where, and also at 23, Parliment- Street, ENGLISH TICKETS and SHARES are selling, engaged, as usual, at the lowest Prices, and in the greatest variety of Numbers. Any Commands will be executed with that Honour and Punctuality whith he flatters himself has distinguished his conduct for a considerable number of years.
(Freeman's Journal of Thursday, 2 December 1802)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
